RenderScript is a framework for running computationally intensive tasks on Android with high performance. RenderScript is primarily used for data-parallel computation, but serial workloads can also benefit from it. The RenderScript runtime can parallel schedule work across multiple processors available on a device, such as multi-core CPUs and GPUs. This allows you to focus on expressing algorithms rather than scheduling work. RenderScript is particularly useful for applications performing image processing, computational photography, or computer vision.

zipalign is a zip archive alignment tool that helps ensure all uncompressed files in the archive are aligned relative to the start of the file. This allows you to access these files directly through mmap(2) without copying this data into RAM, reducing the application's memory usage. zipalign uses 4-byte boundary alignment to map memory, improving execution efficiency by trading space for time. Optimize your APK files with zipalign before distributing them to end users.

WGS84 is a geodetic coordinate system and is the coordinate system used by the widely-used GPS global positioning system. GCJ02, also known as Mars Coordinate System, is a geospatial coordinate system formulated by the National Mapping Bureau of China, obtained by encrypting WGS84. In China, all coordinates must be shifted by the National Mapping Bureau, thus requiring GPS coordinates to be converted.

PJSIP is a free open-source multimedia communication library implemented in C. FUSE (Filesystem in Userspace) is an interface for userspace programs to export a filesystem to the Linux kernel. The FUSE project consists of two components: the fuse kernel module (maintained in the regular kernel repositories) and the libfuse userspace library (maintained in this repository). libfuse provides the reference implementation for communicating with the FUSE kernel module. A FUSE file system is typically implemented as a standalone application that links with libfuse. libfuse provides functions to mount the file system, unmount it, read requests from the kernel, and send responses back. libfuse offers two APIs: a "high-level", synchronous API, and a "low-level" asynchronous API.

The Chromium project has a general utility library referred to as libbase. Because it is standalone and does not depend on any other parts of Chromium, it has been picked up by other Google related projects so people don't have to reinvent these things. Along those lines, a package in Chromium OS is provided so that projects specific to us can share the code without having to bundle it multiple times over. Currently, there are over 20 such projects in Chromium OS. To keep people on their toes, the package is named libchrome as libbase by itself is too confusing. Granted, libchrome isnt exactly clear itself, but its a lose-lose situation, and we tried our best. Please still love us.
